NOTES: ﻿This source would imply that there was a St. Francis Church here at one point; however, it seems like it was either abandoned or destroyed or changed names

﻿I believe this is the same church, or grew out of the same congregation. Per the church's site, Catholic congregated and held service on their own before a priest was sent in. The fact the almanac says vacant speaks to this historic fact. As such, I am saying this is the same institution, or a precursor to it, and keeping the ID for that reason: https://www.stmarybasilica.org/history/
﻿I don't think this place exists anymore. Also, the fact that this location is identified by county/parish, rather than city, makes it quite difficult to find info on.

instName: ﻿Convent and Academy of the Ladies of the Sacred Heart
NOTES: ﻿"Acadia Parish" wasn't an actual Parish (county) in 1835.  Instead, it seems to be gesturing towards a place Acadians settled (the Acadian Coast) http://louisianeacadien.com/acadiachurches.html
courses: ﻿Elements of Botany, Chemistry, Natural Philosophy, and Geometry, Reading, Writing, Grammar, English, French, Arithmetie, History Ancient and Modern, Chronology, Mythology, English and French Polite Literature, Geography, Elements of Astronomy, the Use of the Globes, Domestic Economy, plain and fancy Needle-Work, Embroidery, Marking, Lace work, Music, Drawing, and other fine arts, are paid extra.

﻿The system of instruction embraces the following objects: the English and French languages, Writing, Arithmetic, Geography, the use of the Globes, History ancient and modern) Mythology, Chronology, English and French Literature, Elements of Astronomy, Plain and Fancy Needle-Work. The Elements of Natural Philosophy, of Botany and Chemistry, will be taught to those young Ladies, whose parents desire it. as also Music, Drawing and Dancing.

affiliated: ﻿conducted by the Ladies of the Sacred Heart
﻿conducted by the Ladies of the Sacred Heart
